Award.AbstractNarration:
This travel grant supports the participation of US-based graduate students and other early career mathematicians in the international conference "Theory and Application of Syzygies" held in Saarbrucken, Germany on July 1-3, 2015. The central topic of the conference is the study of syzygies in mathematics, which involves matrices whose entries are polynomials. These kinds of matrices arise throughout pure and applied mathematics, and thus research about syzygies can be applied in many fields, including computational algebra and algebraic geometry. The meeting will provide an excellent opportunity for junior mathematicians to learn about major new developments in these fields and to seek new research problems to explore.

The conference brings together leading experts on syzygies and related topics across a range of fields, and it will highlight many of the recent breakthroughs in the study of syzygies. Due to its relatively moderate size, this conference offers a unique opportunity for this array of top researchers on syzygies to come together and discuss avenues for new research. In addition, since many groundbreaking results on syzygies take place at an intersection between multiple fields, this conference offers a high potential to spur new collaborations or avenues for research.

For more details, see the conference web site http://www.math.uni-sb.de/ag-schreyer/conference/ .

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant was used to promote the training of graduate students through travel funding to two mathematics conferences covering recent research breakthroughs on syzygies and related fields.  

 

The first conference was the international conference "Theory and Application of Syzygies", held in Saarbrucken, Germany in July 2015, and of which the PI was an organizer.  The conference was considered an a huge success, with many excellent talks from 10 global experts, including David Eisenbud, Gavril Farkas, Claire Voisin, and more.  Funding from this grant was used to cover travel expenses for US graduate students and early career mathematicians, allowing them to attend the conference and hear about the cutting edge research discussed.  Beyond being exposed to new ideas in the field, graduate students also had the opportunity to discuss their work with experts, leaving with new ideas for their own research programs.

 

The second conference was the conference "CA+" held at Madison, WI in November 2016.  This is a conference in commutative algebra, jointly hosted (in alternate years) by the University of Wisconsin-Madison and the University of Minnesota.  The goal of the conference is build community among students and researchers interested in commutative algebra at our two institutions, and to expose graduate students at our two institutions to cutting edge ideas that are relevant to their own research.   Funding from this grant was used to cover lodging expenses for US graduate students, primarily from our partner institution, the University of Minnesota.  Our post-conference survey revealed that the conference was a huge success, with one student writing:  "Out of all the conferences I have attended CA+ is one of my favorites. The sense of community it creates amongst mathematicians from various fields and in various periods of their career is really special. I left it excited by the new connections I had made, and the new mathematics I learnt."
